I returned to the state's bitter.
I was heartened when I returned.
Though I was comfortable in a combat environment, I wondered if I would feel at home among civilized
people who wouldn't be able to understand how a soldier thinks and feels.
This takes time and it's never easy.
Even today, when I look at a man or woman, I can't help but judge them.
Does he have leadership capabilities?
Would she be good in combat?
Does he or she have what it takes?
When you come home, those are things I think everybody goes through.
You're looking at people, you're kind of judging people.
It certainly will leave a mark.
I'll tell you, I don't think there's enough veterans now.
You're not going to be able to just hang around with veterans.
It's not going to happen.
You've got to understand and accept the fact that not everyone served the way you served.
That's just the way it is.
And I try to make sure that I don't outwardly hold people to a higher expectation.
Any other thing is, I think you have to walk a fine line and you've got to make sure you're not looking down on people
because they didn't choose the path that you chose.
I think we veterans right now have to use some caution before just shutting out everyone else that didn't serve the way we did.
You probably be shutting out most of the people in your lives.
Most of my friends outside the civil teams, they're, you know, Jiu-Jitsu.
I've got a bunch of friends from Jiu-Jitsu, none of them served.
I can't just shut them all out.
So I think we have to be careful about that as veterans to make sure we...
You're going to have those feelings understood.
Understand that there's more than that.
And you've got to accept other things going on the road besides the one we did.
